node.title: Multi-Region Cassandra Clusters
node.content:
Multi-Region Cassandra Clusters

  1. 1. Novel Multi-region Clusters Cassandra Deployments Split Between Heterogeneous Data Centres with NAT & DNS-SD #CassandraSummit
  2. 2. Adam Zegelin Co-founder & VP of Engineering www.instaclustr.com adam@instaclustr.com‚Ä® @adamzegelin
  3. 3. Instaclustr ‚Ä¢ Instaclustr provides Cassandra-as-a-service in the cloud‚Ä® (Currently only on AWS ‚Äî Google Cloud in private beta) ‚Ä¢ We currently manage 50+ Cassandra nodes for various customers ‚Ä¢ We often get requests to do cool things ‚Äî and try and make it happen!
  4. 4. Multi-DC @ Instaclustr ‚Ä¢ Cloud ‚áÑ cloud, ‚Äúclassic‚Äù internet-facing data centre ‚áÑ cloud ‚Ä¢ Works out-of-the-box today. ‚Ä¢ Requires per-node public IP ‚Ä¢ Private network clusters ‚áÑ Cloud clusters ‚Ä¢ Easy if your private network allocates per-node public IP addresses ‚Ä¢ VPNs ‚Ä¢ Something else?
  5. 5. ‚Ä¢ Overview of multi- region/data centre clusters ‚Ä¢ What is supported out-of-the-box ‚Ä¢ Alternative solutions ‚Ä¢ Supporting technology overview (NAT/PAT and DNS-SD) ‚Ä¢ Implementation
  6. 6. Single Node ‚Ä¢ What you get from running apt-get install cassandra and /usr/bin/ cassandra ‚Ä¢ Fragile (no redundancy) ‚Ä¢ Dev/test/sandbox only C*
  7. 7. Multi-node, Single Data Centre ‚Ä¢ Two or more servers running Cassandra within one DC ‚Ä¢ Replication of data (redundancy) ‚Ä¢ Increased capacity (storage + throughput) ‚Ä¢ Baseline for production clusters C* C* C*
  8. 8. Multi-node, Multi-DC ‚Ä¢ Cassandra running in two or more data centres ‚Ä¢ Global deployments ‚Ä¢ Data near your customers (reduced latency) ‚Ä¢ Supported out-of-the-box C* C* C* C* C* C* C* C* C*
  9. 9. Snitches ‚Ä¢ Understands data centres and racks ‚Ä¢ Implementation may automatically determine node DC and rack‚Ä® (EC2MultiRegionSnitch uses AWS internal metadata service, GossipingPropertiesFileSnitch loads a .properties Ô¨Åle) ‚Ä¢ Node DC and rack is advertised via Gossip ‚Ä¢ Determine node proximity (estimated link latency) ‚Ä¢ Cluster may use a combination of Snitch implementations
  10. 10. Data Centres ‚Ä¢ Collection of Racks ‚Ä¢ Complete replications ‚Ä¢ Geographically separate ‚Ä¢ Possibly high-latency interconnects‚Ä® (e.g. East Coast US ‚Üí Sydney, ~300ms round-trip)
  11. 11. Racks ‚Ä¢ Collection of nodes ‚Ä¢ May fail as a single unit ‚Ä¢ Modelled on the traditional DC rack/cage‚Ä® (n-servers running of a UPS)
  12. 12. ‚òÅ ‚Ä¢ Amazon Web Services‚Ä® (use EC2MultiRegionSnitch) ‚Ä¢ Data Centre ‚â° AWS Region‚Ä® (e.g. US_East_1, AP_SOUTHEAST_2) ‚Ä¢ Rack ‚â° Availability Zone‚Ä® (e.g. us-east-1a, ap-southeast-2b) ‚Ä¢ Google Cloud Platform‚Ä® (no out-of-the-box auto-conÔ¨Åguring snitch ‚Äî use GossipingPropertiesFileSnitch, or roll your own!) ‚Ä¢ Data Centre ‚â° GCP Region‚Ä® (e.g. US, Europe) ‚Ä¢ Rack ‚â° Zone‚Ä® (e.g. us-central1-a, europe-west1-a)
  13. 13. Data Centre Aware ‚Ä¢ Cassandra is data centre aware ‚Ä¢ Only fetch data from a remote DC if absolutely required‚Ä® (remote data is more ‚Äúexpensive‚Äù) ‚Ä¢ Clients can be made data centre aware ‚Ä¢ If your app knows its DC, client will talk to the closest DC
  14. 14. Cluster cluster = Cluster.builder() .addContactPoint(‚Ä¶) .withLoadBalancingPolicy(new DCAwareRoundRobinPolicy(‚ÄúUS_EAST_1")) .build();
  15. 15. Multi DC Support ‚Ä¢ Per-node public (internet-facing) IP address ‚Ä¢ Optionally, per-node private IP address ‚Ä¢ Per-node public address is used for inter-data centre connectivity ‚Ä¢ Per node private address is used for intra-data centre connectivity
  16. 16. Multi DC Support ‚Ä¢ Cloud ‚áÑ cloud, traditional ‚áÑ cloud, traditional ‚áÑ traditional ‚Ä¢ Easy to setup per-node public and private addresses ‚Ä¢ Private network clusters ‚áÑ Cloud clusters ‚Ä¢ Private networks: ùëõ public addresses, shared by ùë• private addresses. Not 1 ‚Üî 1‚Ä® (where often ùë• > ùëõ) ‚Ä¢ done via Network Address Translation
  17. 17. IPv4 Address Space Exhaustion Source: http://www.potaroo.net/tools/ipv4/
  18. 18. Multi-DC Support ‚Ä¢ IPv4 ‚Ä¢ Address exhaustion ‚Ä¢ Over time, will become more expensive to purchase addresses ‚Ä¢ Wasteful‚Ä® (being a good internet citizen)
  19. 19. Alternatives ‚Ä¢ IPv6 ‚Ä¢ Java supports it ‚à¥ Cassandra probably supports it‚Ä® (untested by us) ‚Ä¢ Global IPv6 adoption is ~4%‚Ä® (according to Google ‚Äî¬†google.com/intl/en/ipv6/statistics.html) ‚Ä¢ IPv6/IPv4 hybrid‚Ä® (Teredo, 6over4, et. al.) ‚Ä¢ AWS EC2 does not support IPv6. End of story.‚Ä® (Elastic Load Balancer does support IPv6)
  20. 20. Alternatives ‚Ä¢ VPNs ‚Ä¢ tinc, OpenVPN, etc. ‚Ä¢ All private address space ‚Äî no dual addressing ‚Ä¢ Requires multiple links ‚Äî between every DC and per client ‚Ä¢ Address space overlaps between multiple VPNs ‚Ä¢ Connectivity to multiple clusters an issue‚Ä® (for multi-cluster apps, centralised monitoring, etc)
  21. 21. Data Centres Links 3 3 5 10 7 21
  22. 22. Alternatives ‚Ä¢ Network Address Translation (NAT)‚Ä® (aka IP Masquerading or Port Address Translation (PAT)) ‚Ä¢ Deployed on most private networks ‚Ä¢ Connectivity between private network clusters ‚áÑ Cloud clusters ‚Ä¢ Supports client connectivity to multiple clusters
  23. 23. NAT Basics ‚Ä¢ Re-maps IP address spaces‚Ä® (e.g. Public 96.31.81.80 ‚Üî Private 192.168.*.*) ‚Ä¢ ùëõ public addresses, shared by ùë• private addresses. Not 1 ‚Üî 1‚Ä® (where often n = 1, ùë• Ôºû ùëõ) ‚Ä¢ Port Address Translation ‚Ä¢ Private port ‚Üî Public port ‚Ä¢ Outbound connections only without port forwarding or NAT traversal ‚Ä¢ Per DC gateway device ‚Äî performs NAT and port forwarding
  24. 24. NAT with Inbound Connections ‚Ä¢ Static port forwarding‚Ä® (conÔ¨Ågured on the gateway) ‚Ä¢ Automatic port forwarding ‚Äî UPnP, NAT-PMP/PCP‚Ä® (conÔ¨Ågured by the application, e.g. Cassandra) ‚Ä¢ NAT Traversal ‚Äî STUN, ICE, etc.
  25. 25. NAT + C‚àó Situation: ùëõ Cassandra nodes, 1 public address per data centre ‚Ä¢ Port forward different public ports for each node ‚Ä¢ Advertise assigned ports ‚Ä¢ Modify Cassandra and client applications to connect to advertised ports
  26. 26. Advertising Port Mappings ‚Ä¢ Extend Cassandra Gossip ‚Ä¢ Include port numbers in node address announcements ‚Ä¢ Allow seed node addresses to include port numbers ‚Ä¢ Allow multiple nodes to have identical public & private addresses‚Ä® (only port numbers differ per DC) ‚Ä¢ How to bootstrap? SIP? ‚Ä¢ Cassandra must be aware of the allocated ports in order to advertise ‚Ä¢ Hard if C* is not directly responsible for the port mapping‚Ä® (e.g. static port forwarding) ‚Ä¢ Too many modiÔ¨Åcations to internals
  27. 27. Advertising Port Mappings ‚Ä¢ DNS-SD ‚Äî dns-sd.org‚Ä® (aka Bonjour/Zeroconf) ‚Ä¢ Reads ‚Äî works with existing DNS implementations‚Ä® (it‚Äôs just a DNS query) ‚Ä¢ Even inside restrictive networks, DNS usually works ‚Ä¢ Combination of DNS TXT, SRV and PTR records. ‚Ä¢ Updates ‚Ä¢ via DNS Update & TSIG ‚Äî supported by bind ‚Ä¢ via API ‚Äî e.g. for AWS Route 53
  28. 28. Advertising Port Mappings ‚Ä¢ DNS-SD cont‚Äôd. ‚Ä¢ SRV records contain hostname and port‚Ä® (i.e., hostname of the NAT gateway and public C* port) ‚Ä¢ TXT records contain key=value pairs‚Ä® (useful for additional connection & conÔ¨Åg details) ‚Ä¢ Modify C* connection code to lookup foreign node port from DNS ‚Ä¢ Modify client driver connection code to lookup ports from DNS ‚Ä¢ Can be queried & updated out-of-band‚Ä® (updated by the NAT device or central management server which knows which ports were mapped)
  29. 29. Advertised Details ‚Ä¢ Each cluster is it‚Äôs own browse domain ‚Ä¢ Each NAT gateway device has an A record in the browse domain ‚Ä¢ Each DNS-SD service is named based on the private IP address ‚Ä¢ Requires unique private IP addresses across data centres ‚Ä¢ SRV port is the C* thrift port ‚Ä¢ Additional ports are advertise via TXT
  30. 30. ConÔ¨Åguration ‚Ä¢ Cassandra is conÔ¨Ågured to only use private addresses ‚Ä¢ On cluster creation ‚Ä¢ Establish a new DNS-SD browse domain ‚Ä¢ Create A records for each gateway device ‚Ä¢ NAT gateway device is notiÔ¨Åed when a new C* node is started ‚Ä¢ Allocates random public ports for C* and conÔ¨Ågures Port Forwarding ‚Ä¢ Updates DNS-SD ‚Ä¢ New SRV and TXT record
  31. 31. $ dns-sd -B _cassandra._tcp 1da53f83-e635-11e3-96eb-2ec9d09504f5.clusters.instaclustr.com.au. Browsing for _cassandra._tcp A/R Flags if Domain Service Type Instance Name Add 3 0 1da53f83-e635-11e3-96eb-2ec9d09504f5.clusters.instaclustr.com.au. _cassandra._tcp. 192-168-2-4 Add 3 0 1da53f83-e635-11e3-96eb-2ec9d09504f5.clusters.instaclustr.com.au. _cassandra._tcp. 192-168-1-2 Add 3 0 1da53f83-e635-11e3-96eb-2ec9d09504f5.clusters.instaclustr.com.au. _cassandra._tcp. 192-168-2-3 Add 3 0 1da53f83-e635-11e3-96eb-2ec9d09504f5.clusters.instaclustr.com.au. _cassandra._tcp. 192-168-2-2 Add 3 0 1da53f83-e635-11e3-96eb-2ec9d09504f5.clusters.instaclustr.com.au. _cassandra._tcp. 192-168-1-4 Add 2 0 1da53f83-e635-11e3-96eb-2ec9d09504f5.clusters.instaclustr.com.au. _cassandra._tcp. 192-168-1-3 $ dns-sd -L 192-168-1-4 _cassandra._tcp 1da53f83-e635-11e3-96eb-2ec9d09504f5.clusters.instaclustr.com.au. Lookup 192-168-1-4._cassandra._tcp.1da53f83-e635-11e3-96eb-2ec9d09504f5.clusters.instaclustr.com.au. 192-168-1-4._cassandra._tcp.1da53f83-e635-11e3-96eb-2ec9d09504f5.clusters.instaclustr.com.au. can be reached at aws- us-east1-gateway.1da53f83-e635-11e3-96eb-2ec9d09504f5.clusters.instaclustr.com.au.:1236 (interface 0) version=2.0.7 cqlport=1237 $ nslookup aws-us-east1-gateway.1da53f83-e635-11e3-96eb-2ec9d09504f5.clusters.instaclustr.com.au. Non-authoritative answer: Name: aws-us-east1-gateway.1da53f83-e635-11e3-96eb-2ec9d09504f5.clusters.instaclustr.com.au Address: 54.209.123.195 Output of dns-sd‚Ä® (Can also use avahi-browse, dig, or any other DNS query tool)
  32. 32. Java Driver ModiÔ¨Åcations ‚Ä¢ This is usually a no-op‚Ä® (the default is IdentityTranslater) ‚Ä¢ Modify translate() to perform a DNS-SD lookup. ‚Ä¢ The address parameter is a node private IP address. ‚Ä¢ Locate a service with a name = private IP address to determine public IP/port. public interface AddressTranslater { public InetSocketAddress translate(InetSocketAddress address); }
  33. 33. Modifying Cassandra ‚Ä¢ Responsible for managing Socket connections. ‚Ä¢ Modify newSocket() to perform a DNS-SD lookup. ‚Ä¢ The endpoint parameter is a node private IP address. ‚Ä¢ Locate a service with a name = private IP address to determine public IP/port public class OutboundTcpConnectionPool { ‚ãÆ public static Socket newSocket(InetAddress endpoint) throws IOException {‚Ä¶}‚Ä® ‚ãÆ }
  34. 34. C* C* C* C* C* C* NAT Gateway NAT Gateway DNS (+ DNS-SD) Server‚Ä® (Route 53, Self-hosted, etc)Client Application
  35. 35. Thanks! Questions? adam@instaclustr.com
